hint.text:
Represent the square number as a product of its prime factors
If each of the distinct prime factors exist in pairs, then the number is a perfect square.

solution.text:
\(_{{(j**m)*(k**n)*l}}_\) can be represented as a product of its prime factors as :
\(_{{(j**m)*(k**n)*l}}_=_{j}_^_{m}_ \times _{k}_^_{n}_ \times _{l}_ \)
\(\Rightarrow _{{(j**m)*(k**n)*l}}_= _{{str(j) + ('\\times '+str(j))*(m-1)}}_ \times _{{str(k) + ('\\times '+str(k))*(n-1)}}_ \times _{l}_\)
Observe carefully that the prime factors \(_{j}_\) and \(_{k}_\) exist in pairs.
The prime factor \(_{l}_\) does not have a pair.
Therefore, the number must be divided by \(_{l}_\) so as to get a perfect square.

content.text: Find the smallest number by which \(_{{(j**m)*(k**n)*l}}_\) must be divided so that the quotient is a perfect square.
